scenarioDescription:
The BD-06 1339 Exoplanetary System


Overview

BD-06 1339 is a star with 0.7 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 66.11 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

BD-06 1339 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the BD-06 1339 system


BD-06 1339 b

BD-06 1339 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2013-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of BD-06 1339 b is 8.586 times the mass of Earth. The radius of BD-06 1339 b is 2.850 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, BD-06 1339 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


BD-06 1339 c

BD-06 1339 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2013-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.43 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of BD-06 1339 c is 54.060 times the mass of Earth. The radius of BD-06 1339 c is 8.380 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, BD-06 1339 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system BD-06 1339, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: BD-06 1339 - System With 2 Exoplanets
